item.title: Liz Truss Resigns After 6 Chaotic Weeks, Igniting New Leadership Fight
item.description: The beleaguered British prime minister relinquished her office after just 44 days of political and economic tumult, the shortest tenure in British history.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Daniel Leal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Liz Truss announced her intention to resign as Britain’s prime minister outside 10 Downing Street in London on Thursday.

item.title: Truss Defied the Markets, and They Ruthlessly Sealed Her Fate
item.description: World leaders buffeted by economic challenges are watching the turmoil in Britain with anything but relish, hoping that Liz Truss’s woes won’t be a harbinger for other countries.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Sam Bush for The New York Times
item.media:description: The scene outside the Bank of England in central London. The market’s swift, withering verdict on Prime Minister Liz Truss’s tax-cutting agenda shattered her credibility.

item.title: Liberated Ukrainians Share Tales of Russian Occupation
item.description: With Russian soldiers pushed out of parts of the Kharkiv region, Ukrainian investigators have been overwhelmed with accounts of detentions, torture and missing relatives, as well as collaboration and property theft.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Ivor Prickett
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oleksandr Avdeev, 60, looked on as a rescue worker worked to exhume the body of his son Serhii Avdeev, who was abducted and killed by Russian forces last month, in Borova.

item.title: Ukraine Rations Power Despite Battle Gains in Kherson
item.description: Russia may be preparing to retreat from the southern city of Kherson, Western analysts say, but Ukraine’s president warned of possible destruction of a dam upstream.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia, Monika Pronczuk and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Podil neighborhood of Kyiv on Thursday. The government asked Ukrainians to cut back on energy usage to ensure enough heat and light during the coming winter months.

item.title: Berlusconi, Caught on Tape Gushing Over Putin, Heightens Anxiety About Italy
item.description: Silvio Berlusconi, the former Italian leader and linchpin of the incoming right-wing government, blames Ukraine’s president for pushing President Vladimir V. Putin to invade.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: The billionaire media mogul Silvio Berlusconi at a rally for his right-wing alliance last month in Rome.

item.title: Ahead of Midterms, Disinformation Is Even More Intractable
item.description: Ahead of the midterm elections, the proliferation of alternative social media sites has helped cement false and misleading information as a defining feature of American politics.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Sheera Frenkel
item.media:credit: Todd Anderson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump’s baseless claims of a stolen election have pulsed through public consciousness despite his banishment from platforms like Facebook and Twitter.

item.title: Lindsey Graham Must Testify in Georgia Elections Inquiry, Court Rules
item.description: A federal appeals court ruled that the senator must appear before the special grand jury that is investigating efforts to overturn Donald J. Trump’s election loss in Georgia.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
item.media:credit: Kevin Dietsch/Getty Images
item.media:description: Senator Lindsey Graham during a Senate Judiciary Committee meeting in Washington last month.

item.title: This Minnesota Race Will Show the Potency of Crime vs. Abortion
item.description: Keith Ellison, the state’s progressive attorney general, faces a Republican challenger who is looking to harness public unease since George Floyd’s murder.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.media:credit: Glen Stubbe/Star Tribune, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Attorney General Keith Ellison of Minnesota, right, and his Republican challenger, Jim Schultz, before a debate in St. Paul.

item.title: The Mysterious Patient in Room 23: The Hermit Baroness
item.description: Birgit Thyssen-Bornemisza led a life of eccentric anonymity and shabby gentility. Then her money got cut off. Then she had a stroke.
item.dc:creator: George Rush, John Leland and Rutu Modan
item.media:credit: Rutu Modan
item.media:description: Scenes from an imagined life: The baroness and her mother in Manhattan.

item.title: Kevin Spacey Is Cleared of Anthony Rapp’s Battery Claim
item.description: A jury found Mr. Spacey not liable in a civil trial. Mr. Rapp, an original cast member in “Rent,” had filed a lawsuit accusing Mr. Spacey of making a sexual advance when Mr. Rapp was 14.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs and Nate Schweber
item.media:credit: Yuki Iwamura/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: After less than an hour and a half of deliberation on Thursday, a jury in the U.S. District Court in Manhattan decided in favor of Kevin Spacey.

item.title: Here’s What Anthony Rapp and Kevin Spacey Said in Their Testimony
item.description: The actors both testified in a civil trial this month over accusations of an encounter in 1986.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs and Nate Schweber
item.media:credit: Joan Marcus/Matt Ross Public Relations, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Anthony Rapp, right, performing in the musical “Rent” in New York in 1996.

item.title: Virginia Uses Treated Wastewater to Shore Up a Drinking Water Aquifer
item.description: A crucial aquifer is running low, so officials are pumping in treated sewage. It’s an increasingly common strategy as heavy demand and climate change strain water supplies.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao
item.media:credit: Kristen Zeis for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sediment sample taken this week in Newport News, Va. A planned recharge well at the site will inject additional treated wastewater into the Potomac Aquifer.

item.title: Investigators in Raleigh Found a Trail of Victims and a Well-Armed Suspect
item.description: A report released by the Raleigh police provides a detailed account of a rampage that left five people dead, and the suspect’s shootout with the police.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas
item.media:credit: Veasey Conway for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mourner prayed at a makeshift memorial at the Hedingham Golf Club in northeast Raleigh, N.C., on Saturday.

item.title: James Corden Would Rather Not Talk About That Balthazar Omelet
item.description: In an interview to promote his coming series, “Mammals,” the actor and late-night host dismissed a flap stemming from an Instagram post accusing him of boorish restaurant behavior. “I think it’s so silly,” he said.
item.dc:creator: Dave Itzkoff
item.media:credit: Evan Agostini/Invision, via Associated Press
item.media:description: James Corden found himself the object of online scorn this week after the restaurateur Keith McNally accused him of abusive behavior toward wait staff.

item.title: Why Republicans Are Surging
item.description: The Democrats have serious holes in their political strategy.
item.dc:creator: David Brooks
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times

item.title: A Town With a Heart, but Few Options, for Migrants
item.description: It’s fruitless to lecture El Paso about the hardship of receiving buses. The government sent it hundreds upon hundreds of people every day.
item.dc:creator: Megan K. Stack
item.media:credit: Ivan Pierre Aguirre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Margelis Polo Negrette, 9, getting a hand from a Customs and Border Protection officer after she and her parents, Marielith Negrette and Eduardo Polo Diaz, crossed the Rio Grande into El Paso in early October, a few days before a policy change that would have barred them from the country.

item.title: Will Gas Prices Doom Democracy?
item.description: Their political salience is ludicrous, and terrifying.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Damon Winter/The New York Times

item.title: How to Strangle Democracy While Pretending to Engage in It
item.description: What can “The Rhetoric of Reaction” still teach us? A lot, it turns out.
item.dc:creator: Carlos Lozada
item.media:credit: Mike Haddad

item.title: We Advised Biden on the Pandemic. Much Work Remains to Face the Next Crisis.
item.description: Even with the successes against Covid, there is much room for improvement.
item.dc:creator: Ezekiel J. Emanuel, David Michaels, Rick Bright and Michael T. Osterholm
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: George Wylesol

item.title: The Soup-Throwing Climate Activists May Have Been Right
item.description: The urgency of the climate crisis demands we consider all tactics.
item.dc:creator: Andreas Malm
item.media:credit: Just Stop Oil, via Associated Press

item.title: No, Capitalism and the Internet Will Not Free China’s People
item.description: The Communist Party’s war on independent thought continues.
item.dc:creator: Ai Weiwei
item.media:credit: Elaine

item.title: Politician, Thy Name Is Hypocrite
item.description: A rape-or-incest exception to anti-abortion laws isn’t humanitarian. It’s a meaningless rhetorical ploy.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins
item.media:credit: Ross D. Franklin/Associated Press

item.title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Andy Rain/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: British Prime Minister Liz Truss delivers a resignation statement outside 10 Downing Street on Thursday.

item.title: We Were Three
item.description: A story of lies, family, America and what Covid revealed, as well as what it destroyed.
item.dc:creator: Nancy Updike, Jenelle Pifer, Julie Snyder and Sophie Allison of Soccer Mommy
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Remembering Loretta Lynn
item.description: A conversation about the country music titan’s sly radicalism and the many readings and misreadings of her work.
item.media:credit: Ethan Miller/Reuters

item.title: Vegetarian Snacks for Diwali and Beyond
item.description: Sweets, extra-crispy samosas, nachos layered with chutney and more recipes.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao
item.media:credit: David Malosh for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Hadas Smirnoff.

item.title: Maryland Will Review 100 Police Death Cases for Signs of Bias
item.description: Testimony in the George Floyd murder trial raised questions about how Maryland had handled similar cases.
item.dc:creator: Shaila Dewan
item.media:credit: Aaron Nesheim for The New York Times
item.media:description: Activists marched through downtown Minneapolis after Derek Chauvin was sentenced for the murder of George Floyd.

item.title: Justice Barrett Rejects Plea to Stop Biden’s Student Loan Debt Plan
item.description: Though the justice’s brief order gave no reasons, it was most likely based on the challenger’s seeming failure to show that it had standing to sue.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Justice Amy Coney Barrett oversees the appeals circuit court that ruled against a Wisconsin taxpayers’ association in the case.

item.title: How the ‘Black Death’ Left Its Genetic Mark on Future Generations
item.description: Scientists have discovered several genetic variants that protect Europeans from the bubonic plague — but also increase the risk of immune disorders.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer

item.title: In His Podcast, Andrew Cuomo Seeks Absolution Without Apology
item.description: The former governor, who resigned after accusations of sexual harassment, ushers in his new podcast in the month that marks five years after the #MeToo movement began.
item.dc:creator: Ginia Bellafante
item.media:credit: Seth Wenig/Associated Press
item.media:description: Andrew M. Cuomo, former governor of New York, has kicked off a new podcast.

item.title: In-Line Skating Is Back — Again
item.description: Once you’re up to speed on the basics, getting outside on Rollerblades is a surprisingly good workout.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Loudin
item.media:credit: Michael Ciaglo for The New York Times

item.title: Breaking Up With Peloton
item.description: The stationary bike’s convenience made it a pandemic winner, but some former fans are done working out at home.
item.dc:creator: Holly Burns
item.media:credit: Erik Carter

item.title: How to Master the Push-Up
item.description: With proper technique, you can get the most out of this simple, yet powerful exercise.
item.dc:creator: Christie Aschwanden
item.media:credit: Zack DeZon for The New York Times

item.title: Speeding Up Your Daily Walk Could Have Big Benefits
item.description: In the largest study to incorporate activity tracker data, picking up the pace paid dividends for long-term health.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: Yana Paskova for The New York Times

item.title: How to Run During the Winter
item.description: If you’re forgoing the treadmill and want to keep logging miles, here’s what you need to keep in mind.
item.dc:creator: Jen A. Miller
item.media:credit: Getty Images
item.media:description: Winter running is about more than just covering your upper and lower body. Staying warm without getting overheated can be a tricky dance.

item.title: Cavetown’s Heartfelt Bedroom Pop Brings Kindness to a Cruel World
item.description: The 23-year-old British singer-songwriter Robin Skinner has a listenership devoted to his sensitive (but not despairing) music.
item.dc:creator: Eric Ducker
item.media:credit: Guy Bolongaro for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The function of music for me is therapeutic,” Skinner said. “Most of my songs come from something sad because it’s my way of making it into something better, or something that I can control when it’s a feeling that I’m finding confusing.”

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
